newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin tells Lebed no reason to quit.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin tells Lebed no reason to quit.

text.p: Russian President Boris Yeltsin urged security chief Alexander Lebed on Thursday to stay on in his post, the Kremlin press service said in a statement which suggested the retired general had threatened to quit.

The press service said Lebed was unhappy over the appointment of his predecessor as national security adviser to head a committee on senior military appointments and added: "The president stated that A.I. Lebed does not have enough grounds to raise the issue of leaving his post over this."

"The president urged A.I. Lebed to continue carrying out his duties and to make more effort to work with the government," the statement added. It was issued after Lebed's first meeting with Yeltsin in two months.

Earlier, a spokesman for Lebed told Ekho Moskvy radio there was no truth in a rumour that the security chief had threatened to resign following a hostile reception in parliament on Wednesday when he presented his Chechen peace accord.
Yeltsin, in a radio address on Thursday morning, pointedly praised Lebed for ending the bloodshed in Chechnya but added that there was still work to be done on the peace settlement.

Lebed and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin were due to meet Chechen separatist leader Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev in Moscow on Thursday afternoon. Yeltsin told Lebed: "We must conduct the negotiations with Yandarbiyev subtly and wisely."
